title: Life and Correspondence of David Hume, Volume I (of 2)
author: Burton, John Hill

title: Life and Correspondence of David Hume, Volume I (of 2)
author: Burton, John Hill
snippet: "I find in Hall's Chronicle that the Earl of Surrey, in an inroad uponthe Merse, made during the reign of Henry the Eighth, after the battleof Flouden, destroyed the castles of Hedderburn, West Nisgate, andBlackadder, and the towers of East Nisgate, and Winwalls.

title: Life and Correspondence of David Hume, Volume I (of 2)
author: Burton, John Hill
snippet: "The late Sir James Home of Blackadder showed me a paper, which hehimself had copied a few days before from a gravestone in the churchyardof Hutton: the words were these--'Here lies John Home of Bell, son ofJohn Home of Ninewells, son of John Home of Tinningham, son of John LordHome, founder of Dunglas.'

title: The laird of Norlaw.
author: Oliphant
snippet: " Were you at Mrs. Blackadder s ?" asked Katie.

title: The laird of Norlaw.
author: Oliphant
snippet: " Eh, Mistress, Mr. Blackadder s a man in his prime !" cried Marget.

title: The laird of Norlaw.
author: Oliphant
snippet: There s nae such stock in the country as the beasts that are reared at Tyneside ; and I mean to take a leaf out of Mr. Blackadder s book, if I m spared, and see what we can do at Norlaw."

title: The laird of Norlaw.
author: Oliphant
snippet: And Mr. Blackadder returned gloomily from his visit to the attorney, bringing the news that he had no authority to stop proceedings till he consulted with his principal, after which, in good time, and with a look and grasp of Huntley s hand, which were full of meaning, the good farmer, too, took his wife away.

title: The laird of Norlaw.
author: Oliphant
snippet: food Mrs. Blackadder endeavored to support her.

title: The laird of Norlaw.
author: Oliphant
snippet: " Hush, mocker !" cried the distressed clergyman ; " but what is to be done ? Mr. Blackadder, these bairns can not get this money but with time and toil.

title: The laird of Norlaw.
author: Oliphant
snippet: It was pretty Katie Logan, crying herself, and scarcely able to speak, who had been sent down from the widow s room, by Mrs. Blackadder, to find out what the commotion was ; and who, struck with horror and amazement, as at a sacrilege, was terrified to go

title: The laird of Norlaw.
author: Oliphant
snippet: Huntley, with the minister and the principal farmer of the district, Mr. Blackadder, of Tyneside, who happened to be also an old and steady friend of their father, stood at a little distance with the officer, investigating the detainer w r hich kept the dead out of his grave ; the melancholy empty hearse and dismal coaches crept off slowly along the high road ; and Cosmo, trembling in every limb with the violence of his excitement, stood speechless at the door, gazing after them, falling, in the quick revulsion of his temperament, from unnatural passion into utter and prostrate despondency.

title: The laird of Norlaw :
author: Oliphant
snippet: And Mr. Blackadder returned gloomily from his visit to the attorney, bringing the news that he had no authority to stop proceedings till he consulted with his principal, after which, in good time, and with a look and grasp of Huntley's hand, which were full of meaning, the good farmer, too, took his wife away.

title: The laird of Norlaw :
author: Oliphant
snippet: Pretty Katie Logan sat at her feet crying in inarticulate and unreasoning sympathy, which was better for the Mistress than all the wisdom and consolation with which good Mrs. Blackadder  endeavoured to support her.

title: The laird of Norlaw :
author: Oliphant
snippet: Mr. Blackadder, these bairns cannot get this money but with time and toil.

title: The laird of Norlaw :
author: Oliphant
snippet: Huntley, with the minister and the principal farmer of the district, Mr. Blackadder,  of Tjneside, who happened to be also an old and steady friend of their father, stood at a little distance with the officer, investigating  the detainer which kept the dead out of his grave ; the melancholy empty hearse and dismal coaches crept off slowly along the high road; and Cosmo, trembling in every limb with the violence of his excitement, stood speechless at the door, gazing after them, falling, in the quick revulsion of his temperament,  from unnatural passion into utter and prostrate despondency.

title: The white cockade =
author: Grant, James
snippet: If his position was bad before, in the Blackadder Vault, it was incomparably worse now ! He was completely unnerved for a time ; and as he thought over all the present insuperable difficulties, the future doubts and entire dangers of his position, he seemed to have upon his frame the poisoned shirt of Nessus !

title: The white cockade =
author: Grant, James
snippet: " Render it necessary, after tlie episode of this evening, that I mnst commit you to surer ward than the Blackadder Vault affords/"

title: The white cockade =
author: Grant, James
snippet: More than half an hour elapsed before he heard footsteps on the stone stair^ and in the narrow corridor that led to the Blackadder vault.

title: The white cockade =
author: Grant, James
snippet: " The Bass," wrote Blackadder's son, " was a base, cold, and unwholesome prison, all the rooms being ordinarily full of smoke, like to suffocate and choke us, so that my father and other prisoners were necessitated many a time to thrust head and shoulders out of the window to recover breath.

title: The white cockade =
author: Grant, James
snippet: The Blackadder vault wds a bleak and desolate chamber^ the bare stone walls of which were without  wainscoting or even plaster, and were blackened  by smoke from the securely grated fire-place^ and discoloured by the damp sea breeze that whistled through the equally well grated windows.

title: The white cockade =
author: Grant, James
snippet: sake is dying away_, along with tlie other heroic virtues /^ and he bore np bravely, but a heavy sigh, almost a groan, escaped him when left by Steinie Lockyett, the warder of the garrison, to his own reflections in the Blackadder vault.

title: The white cockade =
author: Grant, James
snippet: ^^You are to have the Blackadder vault, which has no less than three windows.
